ranked_diseases.explanation: Classic presentation with hypotonia, global developmental delay, short stature, and characteristic facial features including deep-set eyes. Brachycephaly is also commonly seen. Age and presentation highly consistent.
Presents with severe hypotonia and global developmental delay. Brachycephaly is common. Deep-set eyes can occur, though short stature is less typical. Similar genomic region to PWS.
Common cause of hypotonia and global developmental delay with brachycephaly. Short stature develops over time. Deep-set eyes less typical but can occur with facial variations.
Features short stature, developmental delays, and can have deep-set eyes. Hypotonia is common in infancy. Brachycephaly less typical but possible.
Presents with hypotonia, developmental delay, and short stature. Facial features can include deep-set appearance. Brachycephaly occasionally reported.
Features developmental delay, short stature, and characteristic facial features that can include deep-set eyes. Hypotonia common in infancy. Brachycephaly possible.
Presents with hypotonia, developmental delay, short stature, and brachycephaly. Deep-set eyes can be part of the characteristic facial features.
Features include developmental delay, short stature, and characteristic facial features. Hypotonia in infancy is common. Brachycephaly and deep-set eyes can occur.
